text.p: These are the leading stories in the Kenyan press on Tuesday. Reuters has not verified these stories and does not vouch for their accuracy.
- Kenyans have until January 31, 1997 to acquire so-called second generation national identity cards.

- The latest oil exploration data on the potential of Kenya becoming a petroleum producing country indicates a positive outcome although commercially viable deposits that can be exploited remain elusive.
- 96 remand prisoners facing capital offences boycott Nairobi High Court proceedings for the third time on Monday, complaining that they are not fed whenever they attend court.
- In a major political about-turn, Opposition leaders Kenneth Matiba and Raila Odinga call for a government of national unity.
- C.A. Omollo becomes Kenya's first woman district commissioner.
- Kenya Posts and Telecommunications Corporation reduces its international telephone and fascimile tariffs by up to 33 percent from January 1, 1997.
- Kipruto Kirwa, a member of parliament for Cherangani in the Rift Valley, apologises to President Daniel arap Moi for his past utterances which were disrespectful to the president.
- Kenyan police arrest a notorious gangster who they say has been terrorising motorists along the Nairobi-Mombasa highway.
- The government and non-governmetal organisations are urged to come to the rescue of drought-stricken residents in North Eastern province.
